awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Changing Social Policies and Healthcare Implementation
awd_abstract_narration:
SES-1436010
Stefan Timmermans
Amy Zhou
University of California Los Angeles

The project contributes to research on global policy diffusion by examining how and when developing countries challenge global policy prescriptions. In addition, by operating at both the state and local levels, the project shows how national policies are improvised and re-interpreted in their implementation.  This dissertation project traces the uneven diffusion of global health priorities to national policy and implementation. International organizations and states exert influence in shaping the policy decisions of developing countries. Yet developing countries vary in their responses to global policy prescriptions. Under what conditions do developing states diverge from policy prescriptions? How are new policies implemented and improvised upon in resource-constrained settings? This project focuses on a unique case of policy divergence from Malawi, one of the poorest countries in sub-Saharan Africa. In 2011, Malawi went against WHO guidelines and became the first country to adopt an HIV policy called ?Option B+?. The policy significantly expanded access to HIV treatment by providing pregnant and breastfeeding women immediate and lifelong access to treatment upon testing positive. This project examines why Malawi diverged from WHO guidelines to adopt Option B+, and how Malawian healthcare providers and patients understand and act upon this new policy.

Data for the project comes from ethnographic observations and interviews with actors at both the state and local level. At the state level, interviews with members of state agencies and international organizations involved in the Option B+ discussion specifies the unique roles that state and non-state actors have in developing policy. At the local level, interviews and observations at health care centers highlights if and when providers and patients deviate from treatment procedures and the logic that underpins their decisions.
 
Broader Impacts:

Since Malawi's adoption of Option B+, the WHO revised their recommendation in 2012 to include Option B+ as an advantageous third option and several countries in the region are considering the policy change. Because the policy is new and untested, there are key concerns regarding barriers to care, adherence to treatment, and possible tensions between partners and community members. This project can create interdisciplinary dialogue. Sociological insights and the richness of qualitative data can inform public health professionals on the unintended consequences of the policy and possible ways to increase uptake and adherence to HIV medication.

por.por_cntn:
My dissertation is a multi-sited ethnographic study of how global health policies are transformed in local settings. This project was motivated by an empirical puzzle. In 2011, Malawi – a small and poor country in sub-Saharan Africa – diverged from WHO guidelines and developed a new policy for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV (PMTCT). The policy, called Option B+, placed all HIV-positive pregnant and breastfeeding women on lifelong treatment. Malawi made a portion of the population universally eligible for treatment while the WHO recommended that patients start only when their disease progressed to a certain stage. Despite Malawi’s dependence on donor funding, the country pursued and successfully implemented their policy innovation. I use the case of Option B+ to investigate the conditions and processes of policy divergence in the global South. I also examine the unexpected ways that innovations for HIV treatment policy affect local clinic activities and patients’ experiences with treatment.

Data consists of interviews with policymakers (N=25), healthcare providers (N=37), and HIV-positive patients (N=65), as well as 6 months of fieldwork in health centers and archival materials. I argue that despite donor dependence, strong epistemic networks can enable countries to pursue and legitimize their policy agenda. However, biomedical rationales for treatment are not always in line with the needs of local clinics and patients. In a resource-constrained setting, the prioritization of HIV treatment programs transforms services for women’s pregnancy into a means for finding and treating HIV-positive women. For women themselves, immediate economic needs could make it difficult to continue a treatment regimen with side effects that disrupted their ability to work.

This case of divergence complicates a broad literature on policy diffusion that emphasizes the normative and coercive power of global institutions. My findings emphasize the “social skill” or “robust action” of policy entrepreneurs to shift the opinions of national and international experts, and thereby challenge existing WHO guidelines and skepticism from donors. This project also builds on existing research on medical decision-making by situating decisions in a broader political economy of changing HIV policies, economic conditions, and everyday uncertainty. In addition to theoretical contributions, this project has broader relevance for public health interventions. Findings show the limits of disease-based approaches to public health and suggests that increased attention on general healthcare infrastructure is needed. I also show the challenges to starting lifelong HIV treatment immediately. Interventions that provide early treatment support, assistance with disclosing one’s status to partners and family members, and nutritional support may help women start and stay on treatment.  

My research on HIV-positive women’s perceptions of treatment has been published in Social Science & Medicine. I also collaborated with others scholars to write for a public health and applied audience. An article on the barriers and facilitators to HIV treatment adherence has been published in PLOS ONE. Beyond academic publications, my research was featured in an editorial on AIDSMAP and in a blog post for the UCLA Center for the Study of Women. I have also presented my research at major HIV conferences, including the International AIDS Society Conference and International Workshop on HIV Pediatrics.
